title: Martinborough First Impressions: A Square, Wine Streets, and Delicious Eats
excerpt: Four days into my new life in Martinborough, and I'm charmed by this quaint wine town's character, from its distinctive town square to streets named after world cities.
content:
It's been just four days since I properly settled in, and I'm already enchanted by Martinborough's distinctive character. This place is incredibly quaint and small — the entire town center is shaped around a square, which gives it a European village feel that's so different from Auckland's urban sprawl.

One of the first things I noticed while exploring is how all the street names have references to other countries and cities — Venice Street, Dublin Street, and others radiating from the central square. It feels like a tiny world map in the heart of wine country.

And speaking of wine... this place is so wine-oriented that the new development of fancy houses I passed yesterday is literally called "Pinot Place." I laughed out loud when I saw the sign. When your entire town's identity is wrapped around wine production, I guess you embrace it in every aspect of life!

Local Dining Scene

Despite its small size, Martinborough has some surprisingly good food options. I've already tried a few little eateries:

  • Lunar — Great service and an impressive wine range. I've heard about their special Pinot but haven't tried it yet. The staff were incredibly friendly and seemed to know everyone who walked in except me (the obvious newcomer).
  • Tohi — Actually a gin bar, but they also serve some delicious Asian-influenced small plates. The space is cozy and stylish, with a very different vibe from what I expected in a small wine town.
  • Na Ra — Had the most incredible chicken and waffles here! Definitely not what I expected to find in rural New Zealand, but it was perfectly executed with local ingredients.

What stands out most in all these places is the service — it's genuinely warm rather than professionally polished. People take their time to chat, and there's none of that big-city rushing that I had grown accustomed to.

It's fascinating how much the pace of life changes just a few hours from the city. Four days in, and I already feel my shoulders relaxing and my mind slowing down a bit. I'm sure the novelty will wear off eventually, but for now, I'm enjoying being the new face in a place where everyone seems to know each other.

Tomorrow I'll venture a bit further to explore some of the surrounding vineyards. Being autumn, the vines are turning beautiful shades of gold and red, which I've been told makes for spectacular photos. I'm also hoping to try that famous Lunar Pinot — purely for research purposes, of course!
